title: 107_hr1509
content: The Act titled "National Media Campaign to Prevent Underage Drinking Act of 2001" amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a national media campaign aimed at preventing underage drinking. The Act establishes a national media campaign to reduce and prevent underage drinking in the US, based on scientific research and conducted through the Office of Public Health and Science. The Secretary will supplement existing efforts to prevent underage drinking and coordinate with various federal agencies and departments. The Secretary will use funds for a national media campaign targeting prevention and treatment resources in specific geographic areas, with language-appropriate messages for minority groups. The advertising portion of the campaign will receive sufficient funds to meet reach and frequency goals. The national media campaign will use funds for development, media purchase, talent payments, production costs, testing, and evaluation to meet reach and frequency goals. The national media campaign will use funds for development, media purchase, talent payments, production costs, testing, and evaluation to meet reach and frequency goals. Funds may also be used for partnerships with community, civic, and professional groups, government organizations, and entertainment industry collaborations related to the campaign. The curr_chunk discusses collaborations in the entertainment industry for underage-drinking prevention messages in various media formats. It also outlines prohibitions on the use of funds to supplant community efforts and current pro bono services by broadcasting networks. The curr_chunk prohibits the use of funds for partisan political purposes, media campaigns featuring elected officials, and advertising messages with company logos. The curr_chunk outlines the requirement for non-Federal contributions to a national media campaign on underage drinking prevention, equal to 50% of the purchase price of media time or space. Additionally, it mandates the Secretary to report to Congress on the comprehensive strategy within 6 months of enactment. The Secretary must develop and submit a comprehensive strategy to Congress within 6 months of enactment, outlining the nature of underage drinking, scientific basis, target audiences, goals, message points, implementation plan, evaluation plan, and costs. Annual reports on activities funded under subsection (e) must also be submitted to Congress. The Secretary must provide Congress with an annual report on the activities funded for underage drinking prevention, including details on the national media campaign's performance. A progress report on the campaign's measurable outcomes must be submitted within one year. The term 'underage drinking' is defined as the consumption of alcohol by individuals below the legal purchasing age in their state. Funding for these initiatives is also outlined. Funding for prevention activities is authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2007, with a limitation on expenditures for specific strategy activities.
